items.body:
```
$ pip install cbor2
Collecting cbor2
  Using cached cbor2-5.1.2.tar.gz (73 kB)
Building wheels for collected packages: cbor2
  Building wheel for cbor2 (setup.py) ... done
  Created wheel for cbor2: filename=cbor2-5.1.2-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl size=173916 sha256=a5197fd079744f4d0e09bebb936e7a3ee6b7a8d3ef62cdab1f05c5fbf1c9e089

Successfully installed cbor2-5.1.2
$ python
Python 3.8.2 (default, Jul 16 2020, 14:00:26) 
[GCC 9.3.0] on linux
>>> import io,cbor2

>>> cbor2.load(fp)
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```

Expected behaviour: Exception

items.title: Segmentation fault at shutdown
items.body:
I've found a segmentation fault that I could reproduce on different machines, yet failed to pin down any further. As cbor2 is the only non-standard module involved I could not remove (started with four), I'm reporting this here. Please bear with me as some parts of this seem like no-ops, but I haven't found anything in this I could remove:

* Use a recent Debian sid (any state in the last few days should do, as systems I tested with ranged from not updated since end of May to freshly set up).
* `git clone https://github.com/agronholm/cbor2` (alternatively, wget and unpack [5.1.0](https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/ee/80/bc617b7fd89855649e48eb8242e09535e1b75371ec8389313fa0f97e2a70/cbor2-5.1.0.tar.gz)).
* `python3 setup.py build`
* Create a `/tmp/test.py` containing

```python
import inspect
import cbor2
import csv
```

* `PYTHONPATH=build/lib.linux-x86_64-3.8 python3 /tmp/test.py`

On the first run, all is fine. On the second and subsequent runs, this segfaults. (No error message is printed, so unless your shell shows error codes, look at the return code).

Various observations I've made which didn't get me any further but might help you:

* This only happens at shutdown. When I found this, I was running through my test suite, which always passed, but segfaulted for some test cases to be run but not for others. The above is the minimal error case distilled from that.
* The first-run behavior stems from the `.pyc` files in the build directory. (Which is good because it's the only legitimate kind-of-reason I could come up with for this).
* The `-d -v -X faulthandler` arguments don't affect the segmentation fault, and may help in debugging.
* Running Python with `-X dev` or `-X tracemalloc` cause the error to disappear.
* `python -c "import inspect; ..."` does not cause the error.
* The last import can be replaced with other simple modules like argparse or socket. For the first import, I haven't found suitable substitutes.
* Running in gdb gives me the following traceback:

```backtrace
#0  unlink_chunk (p=p@entry=0xa45f60, av=0x7ffff7f75b80 <main_arena>) at malloc.c:1466
#1  0x00007ffff7e3fcc5 in _int_free (av=0x7ffff7f75b80 <main_arena>, p=0xa45f60, have_lock=<optimized out>) at malloc.c:4333
#2  0x00000000005ca653 in _Py_Dealloc (op=<optimized out>) at ../Objects/object.c:2215
#3  _Py_DECREF (filename=<synthetic pointer>, lineno=541, op=<optimized out>) at ../Include/object.h:478
#4  _Py_XDECREF (op=<optimized out>) at ../Include/object.h:541
#5  free_keys_object (keys=0xa3aec0) at ../Objects/dictobject.c:584
#6  0x00000000005caffc in dictkeys_decref (dk=0xa3aec0) at ../Objects/dictobject.c:324
#7  dict_dealloc (mp=0x7ffff76a5640) at ../Objects/dictobject.c:1998
#8  0x000000000069d953 in _Py_DECREF (filename=0x87d3e8 "../Objects/moduleobject.c", lineno=791, op=<optimized out>) at ../Include/object.h:478
#9  module_clear (m=<optimized out>) at ../Objects/moduleobject.c:791
#10 0x00000000004ec288 in delete_garbage (state=<optimized out>, state=<optimized out>, old=0x934820 <_PyRuntime+416>, collectable=0x7fffffffdcd0) at ../Modules/gcmodule.c:948
#11 collect.constprop.0 (generation=generation@entry=2, n_collected=n_collected@entry=0x0, n_uncollectable=n_uncollectable@entry=0x0, nofail=nofail@entry=1, 
    state=0x9347d8 <_PyRuntime+344>) at ../Modules/gcmodule.c:1123
#12 0x000000000066ab3b in _PyGC_CollectNoFail () at ../Modules/gcmodule.c:1866
#13 0x000000000067d580 in PyImport_Cleanup () at ../Python/import.c:542
#14 0x0000000000677ad0 in Py_FinalizeEx () at ../Python/pylifecycle.c:1240
#15 0x00000000006aea19 in Py_RunMain () at ../Modules/main.c:646
#16 0x00000000006aec89 in Py_BytesMain (argc=<optimized out>, argv=<optimized out>) at ../Modules/main.c:698
#17 0x00007ffff7ddfe0b in __libc_start_main (main=0x4eb6e0 <main>, argc=2, argv=0x7fffffffe018, init=<optimized out>, fini=<optimized out>, rtld_fini=<optimized out>, 
    stack_end=0x7fffffffe008) at ../csu/libc-start.c:308
#18 0x00000000005f59da in _start () at ../Objects/obmalloc.c:1233
```
I didn't find any local that I could make sense of, especially with all the op being optimzied out.

I'll try to keep the particular setup around in case you can't repoduce it, but have ideas on which experiments to make with this.

items.title: C backend won't be built on most platforms due to glibc version check
items.body:
Impacted: v5.1.0, master@5e8491f

cbor2 does a check that a new enough glibc is installed before enabling the C backend. It does this using the value returned by `platform.libc_ver()`. Unfortunately, this value can't be relied upon  on many versions of Python (seems like anything less than Python 3.8 because 3.8 has [bpo-35389](https://bugs.python.org/issue35389)).

For example, on Python 3.7:
```
❯ docker run --rm python:3.7-slim python -c 'import platform; print(platform.libc_ver())'
('glibc', '2.2.5')
```
...this is less than the version cbor2 requires (2.9) but the OS actually has glibc 2.28:
```
❯ docker run --rm python:3.7-slim ldd --version | head -n 1
ldd (Debian GLIBC 2.28-10) 2.28
```

Note that pip implements its own version of `libc_ver()` to get around this: https://github.com/pypa/pip/blob/20.1.1/src/pip/_internal/utils/glibc.py#L70-L87

items.title: Installation requires a compiler
items.body:
Currently, installing cbor2 fails if a compiler isn't installed. See https://github.com/agronholm/cbor2/blob/5e8491fe9449cbb4990d36e1fee2c93e9a10a499/setup.py#L24

There is a pure python fallback, but it seems the current setup.py will not actually use it most of the time. It would be great if the setup.py could check to see if compilation succeeds/could succeed, and fallback to pure python if the compilation fails. 

Alternatively publishing wheels for all common platforms would be great as well.

items.title: cbor encoded message can not be passed to machine with different endianness
items.body:
Dear

It seems impossible to transmit data in between machines when they have different endiannes.
The encoded version of a single data structure is different on different endiannes machines.

Below the tests I have executed on a mips (big endian) and a intel (little endian) sending a dict with some data.

Both using version 5.0.1. On the mips machine I tested using pure python version and using compiled version

### intel device (little endian)
>>> sys.byteorder                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        
'little'
>>> d = {1: 'test1', 2: 2, 3:b'123456789'}                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
>>> cbor2.dumps(d)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      
b'\xa3\x01etest1\x02\x02\x03I123456789'
>>> cbor2.loads(cbor2.dumps(d))                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
{1: 'test1', 2: 2, 3: b'123456789'}
>>> cbor2.loads(b'\x1d\x08+test1\x10\x10\x18J123456789') 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
CBORDecodeError                           Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-12-358b0f597a24> in <module>
----> 1 cbor2.loads(b'\x1d\x08+test1\x10\x10\x18J123456789')

~/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cbor2/decoder.py in loads(payload, **kwargs)
    429     """
    430     fp = BytesIO(payload)
--> 431     return CBORDecoder(fp, **kwargs).decode()
    432 
    433 

~/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cbor2/decoder.py in decode(self, shareable_index)
    397         decoder = major_decoders[major_type]
    398         try:
--> 399             return decoder(self, subtype, shareable_index)
    400         except CBORDecodeError:
    401             raise

~/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cbor2/decoder.py in decode_uint(decoder, subtype, shareable_index, allow_indefinite)
     30         return None
     31     else:
---> 32         raise CBORDecodeError('unknown unsigned integer subtype 0x%x' % subtype)
     33 
     34 

CBORDecodeError: unknown unsigned integer subtype 0x1d


**mips device (big endian)**
>>> sys.byteorder
'big'
>>> d = {1: 'test1', 2: 2, 3:b'123456789'}
>>> cbor2.dumps(d)
b'\x1d\x08+test1\x10\x10\x18J123456789'
>>> cbor2.loads(cbor2.dumps(d))
{1: 'test1', 2: 2, 3: b'123456789'}
>>> cbor2.loads(b'\xa3\x01etest1\x02\x02\x03I123456789')
'\x01etest1\x02\x02\x03I123456789'

items.title: `cbor2` cannot be installed when the system locale is C
items.body:
The latest version 5.0.1 of `cbor2` package cannot be installed using `pip` from Python 3 when the system locale is `C`.

It means, in particular, that installation fails if `cbor2` is installed during building of a Docker image based on Ubuntu or Debian, unless the locale is explicitly configured before installing `cbor2`:

`Dockerfile`
```Dockerfile
FROM ubuntu:18.04
RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y python3-pip
RUN pip3 install cbor2==5.0.1
```

```bash
$ docker build .
...
Step 3/3 : RUN pip3 install cbor2==5.0.1
 ---> Running in d25611af1b36
Collecting cbor2==5.0.1
  Downloading https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/3e/2c/188d040bd4cf99012d0e847a3d95bf1ef1f783859b09eb9f736950af84f0/cbor2-5.0.1.tar.gz (72kB)
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
      File "/tmp/pip-build-3fenoodl/cbor2/setup.py", line 52, in <module>
        **kwargs
      File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/setuptools/__init__.py", line 128, in setup
        _install_setup_requires(attrs)
      File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/setuptools/__init__.py", line 121, in _install_setup_requires
        dist.parse_config_files(ignore_option_errors=True)
      File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/setuptools/dist.py", line 491, in parse_config_files
        _Distribution.parse_config_files(self, filenames=filenames)
      File "/usr/lib/python3.6/distutils/dist.py", line 395, in parse_config_files
        parser.read(filename)
      File "/usr/lib/python3.6/configparser.py", line 697, in read
        self._read(fp, filename)
      File "/usr/lib/python3.6/configparser.py", line 1015, in _read
        for lineno, line in enumerate(fp, start=1):
      File "/usr/lib/python3.6/encodings/ascii.py", line 26, in decode
        return codecs.ascii_decode(input, self.errors)[0]
    UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 149: ordinal not in range(128)
    
    ----------------------------------------
Command "python setup.py egg_info" failed with error code 1 in /tmp/pip-build-3fenoodl/cbor2/
The command '/bin/sh -c pip3 install cbor2==5.0.1' returned a non-zero code: 1
```

It is possible to configure the locale before running `pip`, for example by setting it to `en_US.UTF-8`, as suggested in https://github.com/dbohdan/remarshal/issues/24#issuecomment-599047829, but it would be nice if it was possible to install `cbor2` for any system locale.

items.title: CBORSimpleValue differs between C lib and Python
items.body:
A CBORSimpleValue returned by the C library is a subclass of namedtuple instead of the object defined in `cbor2/types.py`

I have a fix on the way.

items.title: Differing results on Python 2.7 and 3.7 when decoding canonical data
items.body:
Stumbled across this today. When decoding the same bit of data, I'm getting results in different orders in Python2 vs 3. 

Python 3.7 is doing what I expect - I can encode the data and end up with the same result as the received, already encoded data. Python 2 provides a different result.

I created a repl to show each case. The code is identical - only the Python version is different (cbor2 v5.0.1). You can find them here:
Python 2.7 - https://repl.it/@thephez/cbor2-py27
Python 3.7 - https://repl.it/@thephez/cbor2-py37

items.title: JSON Compatible flag is not used
items.body:
There is a json_compatible flag mentioned in the documentation and in the encoder __slots__ attribute, but it appears to be unused.

Any objection to removing this, or is there an implementation somewhere?

items.title: Docs/Clarification
items.body:
The `CBOREncoder` docstring says that setting `value_sharing` to `True`, "allows more efficient serializing of repeated values".

The main docs only reference this param in terms of cyclic structures, so I was wondering if there was a benefit to allowing this on non-cyclic but repetitive structures. Something like:

```python
a = <something large but without cycles>
cbor2.dumps({'a': a, 'x': a}, value_sharing=True)
```

items.title: requesting support for decoding multiple objects
cbor2 'types.py' module triggers deprecation warning
items.body:
This is not a high-priority issue (for reasons that will become apparent below), but it will need to be addressed eventually.

The types.py module includes the following import statement:

```python
from collections import Mapping
```

This import triggers the following deprecation warning under python 3.7:

```
DeprecationWarning: Using or importing the ABCs from 'collections' instead of from 'collections.abc' is deprecated, and in 3.8 it will stop working
```

According to the [python 3.8.0b4 changelog](https://docs.python.org/3.8/whatsnew/changelog.html#changelog), the decision to remove the ABC aliases from the collections module has been bumped to python 3.9, so fixing this warning is not immediately necessary (as mentioned above)... but I thought you folks would like to know about the potential problem before it becomes... um... a problem.

Having a starting point, I think I could help debug the problem.

items.title: Decoding the full contents of a cbor-encoded urllib3 HTTPResponse
items.body:
Using cbor2 version 4.1.2 on Python 2.7.

I'm receiving a cbor-encoded [urllib3.response.HTTPResponse](https://urllib3.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference/#urllib3.response.HTTPResponse), which implements [io.ioBase](https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/io.html#io.IOBase).

How do I use cbor2 to decode this stream? Do I use `load`, `loads` or `CBORDecoder`? Can you give an example?

items.title: Mem-leak in loads()
items.body:
Argh, I was afraid I hadn't caught everything in the C-based implementation and so it's turned out. When testing the C-based implementation on piwheels we had it fall over a couple of times with out-of-mem errors. A bit of further testing revealed there was definitely an issue *somewhere* in the C-based implementation but I'm afraid it's taken me about a week to track down exactly where. Turns out it's a trivial ref-leak in the C-based loads() function (it leaks the byte-string it's passed). I've got a patch in the works; just trying to figure out an extension to the ref-leak testing script to catch things like this a bit more easily in future!

Anyway, sorry about that - will post the PR hopefully tomorrow.

items.title: Difference between Float and Double types when writing to CBOR
items.body:
Is there a way to differentiate between float and double when calling cbor2.dumps()? 
I've run into the problem that all floating point values written from Python are treated as double on the receiving end (Scala code). Is there some way to hint that certain values or arrays should be float instead of double?

items.title: schema validation using cddl fails against encoded strings
items.body:
Here is a sample python script I have written to reproduce the issue

```
import os.path
from cbor2 import *

my_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(__file__))
input_cbor_path = os.path.join(my_path, "event.cbor")

obj = {
    "x": "one"
}
with open(input_cbor_path, 'wb') as fp:
    dump(obj, fp)

with open(input_cbor_path, 'rb') as fp:
    parsed_obj = load(fp)
    print parsed_obj
```

I am running the cddl tool to validate the encoded cbor against the schema

`cddl event.cddl validate event.cbor`

The schema (event.cddl) is defined as below:
```
event = {
    x: tstr
}
```

By shallow inspection, it seems there is some issue with the way strings are encoded.

items.title: Combine cboar and cbor2?
items.body:
Not so much an issue this one as a place for discussion of the possibility, raised in #44, of eventually combining the cboar and cbor2 projects (assuming I get cboar finished and released :).

The case *for* merging:

* All cbor2 users get a decent, free speed boost
* There's very little sacrifice of flexibility (though there is *some* - I've already locked down the initial set of encoders in cboar as an optimization because it led to a substantial speed boost)
* There's no sacrifice of functionality (it's basically the same API, right down to the constructor arguments for CBOREncoder and CBORDecoder, though at the moment I haven't bothered with separate exception classes because I thought that bit of cbor2 was a bit odd - naturally I'd change that if the projects were to merge because backwards compatibility would be a concern)

The case *against* merging:

* A C-based library would be less approachable for people to hack on
* A C-based implementation doesn't have the *fairly* strong guarantee against memory leaks that a pure Python version has
* My original thoughts for cboar were that it would remain an "optimized cbor2", i.e. cbor2 would be its "upstream" defining the functionality and API, and that for 99% of users it would be the library of choice while cboar would exist for the 1% running on weird platforms or with weird requirements who needed the speed and were prepared to sacrifice a little flexibility and the memory leak guarantees

Anyway, I'm happy to be persuaded either way but before anybody at the cbor2 end makes a choice I should probably outline some of the changes I've made in [cboar] (there's not many and they're fairly subtle but they might be important). I'll try and find the time to document more of those tonight (or if you're happy perusing C, go have a look at the code!).

Discuss!

[cboar]: https://github.com/waveform80/cboar

items.title: Shared immutable arrays aren't shared after load
items.body:
Another minor (and very esoteric) issue I came across in the course of writing cboar which is probably best illustrated by example:

```python
>>> import cbor2
>>> a = (1, 2, 3)
>>> b = ((a, a), a)
>>> c = cbor2.loads(cbor2.dumps(b, value_sharing=True))
>>> c
[[[1, 2, 3], [1, 2, 3]], [1, 2, 3]]
>>> c[0][0] is c[0][1]
True
>>> c[0][0] is c[1]
True
>>> c = cbor2.loads(cbor2.dumps(set(b), value_sharing=True))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/dave/projects/cbor2/cbor2/decoder.py", line 399, in decode
    return decoder(self, subtype, shareable_index)
  File "/home/dave/projects/cbor2/cbor2/decoder.py", line 142, in decode_semantic
    return semantic_decoder(decoder, value, shareable_index)
  File "/home/dave/projects/cbor2/cbor2/decoder.py", line 253, in decode_set
    return set(value)
TypeError: unhashable type: 'list'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/dave/projects/cbor2/cbor2/decoder.py", line 431, in loads
    return CBORDecoder(fp, **kwargs).decode()
  File "/home/dave/projects/cbor2/cbor2/decoder.py", line 403, in decode
    raise CBORDecodeError('error decoding value at index {}: {}'.format(self.fp.tell(), e))
cbor2.decoder.CBORDecodeError: error decoding value at index 21: unhashable type: 'list'
>>> c = cbor2.loads(cbor2.dumps(set(b), value_sharing=False))
>>> c
{((1, 2, 3), (1, 2, 3)), (1, 2, 3)}
```

The reason this occurs is that `decode_array` the function creates the list in which to decode the contents and sets it as the current shareable (assuming a semantic shareable tag has preceded it). However, if immutable is also set (as it will be when encoding the set in the above example) then once the array has been filled it is replaced with a tuple before return, but the *shareable* that was set earlier is *still the list* (not the newly created tuple).

It's probably enough to simply replace the shareable after constructing the tuple (but before returning it). In cboar I've gone a slightly different route but that's because constructing a tuple and a list is rather similar at the C level (and it's a lot more efficient to construct the tuple on the fly than convert a list afterward, assuming the length is known up front).

There's probably a similar issue with `decode_map` when it's outputting a FrozenDict but I haven't come up with a test case for that yet. Anyway, I'll bash together another PR for this later on.

items.title: Timestamp encoding throws away microseconds
items.body:
I get the impression from `encode_datetime` in encoder.py (https://github.com/agronholm/cbor2/blob/master/cbor2/encoder.py#L138) that the intention for timestamp encoding is to calculate a floating-point value to encode. Unfortunately, integer division (// instead of /) is being used with the microseconds field. Given microseconds can never be >1000000 (the value it is being divided by), the result of the division will always be 0, effectively throwing the microseconds data away.

For example, under Python 3.5:

```python3
>>> import cbor2
>>> import datetime as dt
>>> ts = dt.datetime.now()
>>> cbor2.loads(cbor2.dumps(ts, datetime_as_timestamp=1, timezone=dt.timezone.utc))
datetime.datetime(2019, 4, 16, 21, 16, 9, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)
>>> cbor2.loads(cbor2.dumps(ts, datetime_as_timestamp=0, timezone=dt.timezone.utc))
datetime.datetime(2019, 4, 16, 21, 16, 9, 167883, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)
```

items.title: Find a way to share objects by hash as well as id
items.body:
Right now we only reference an object if it's exactly the same id.
We could however use the hash of the object whenever it is available to share objects since if the hashes are equal the objects should be equivalent and interchangeable.

items.title: dates are encoded as datetimes
items.body:
https://github.com/agronholm/cbor2/blob/bf4acfd4ba08959a8b18f6c97981bae6d9bd22ca/cbor2/encoder.py#L156-L158

In my opinion the default behavior of the encoder should be to refuse to serialize an object if the decoder isn't capable of recreating it exactly. Converting to and from CBOR shouldn't be a lossy operation.

items.title: How to effiently encode a list of dicts
items.body:
I have a program that periodically accumulates a set of data into a dictionary and queues (appends) the dictionary to a list.  When the list gets to a certain size (60), the list is converted to CSV format (using csv.DictWriter).

I want to make the transport usage more efficient and using CBOR seems like a good fit (instead of ascii text).

If I encode each dict using `dumps()`, then each key field is encoded and duplicated.  This is inefficient as there are multiple copies (60) of each key field.

Is there a way to encode this more efficiently with cbor2, where the keys are only represented once? (with csv this encoded in the first line as a header).

Does using something like Pandas or Numpy (or even sqllite3?) and cattrs.unstructure() help in any way?

items.title: Support encoding a stream without first reading it into memory
items.body:
Support encoding a stream without first reading it into memory. Something like:
x = cbor2.dumps({"name": open("file.zip", "rb")})

(The other part of this would be to then return a file-like object from which the caller can read the encoded stream, so that neither the input nor the output ever needs to be entirely in memory.)

items.title: Bigint encoding takes quadratic O(n^2) time
items.body:
> The code seems to be a long integer time complexity O (n ^ 2)?
> Let's say I have a 10,000 bit integer

_Originally posted by @fsssosei in https://github.com/agronholm/cbor2/issues/28#issuecomment-435314182_

The repeated divisions and inserting at the beginning of the list get noticeably slow once you get to about 100000 digits.

```python
>>> timeit(lambda: cbor2.dumps(2**200), number=50000)
1.3028403969080813
>>> timeit(lambda: cbor2.dumps(2**2000), number=50000)
12.468400787521446
>>> timeit(lambda: cbor2.dumps(2**20000), number=50000)
710.3362544665841
>>> 
```

items.title: Overflow error encoding large float with canonical=True
items.body:
```python
>>> cbor2.dumps(1e300, canonical=True)
OverflowError: float too large to pack with f format
```

Using cbor2 4.1.1.

items.title: encode_decimal loses sign information.
items.body:
expected Behaviour:

```python
>>> from cbor2 import dumps, loads
>>> from decimal import Decimal
>>> a = Decimal('-0.3')
>>> loads(dumps(a))
Decimal('-0.3')
```
Actual behaviour:

```python
>>> from cbor2 import dumps, loads
>>> from decimal import Decimal
>>> a = Decimal('-0.3')
>>> loads(dumps(a))
Decimal('0.3')
```

What's happening is that the sign information is not being added to the mantissa during encoding.

I will submit a pull request if I get time in the next few days.

items.title: Is it possible to return an iterator or generator for indefinite length data types?
items.body:
Let's say I have a large file with streamed data items in a CBOR indefinite array.

What's the most efficient way to stream them?

And could this be done with more than one indefinite stream in a single file (for example if the app streaming to the file had to close it and then re-open it)

I am thinking of something like the following:

```python
with open('data.cbor', 'rb') as f:
    s = load_streaming(f)
    header = s[0]
    rows = s[1] # returns an iterator
    counter = 0
    for row in rows:
        if row[1] > 53:
            counter += 1
    print('count:', counter)
```

items.title: CBOR supports Arrays and bytestrings as Map keys, but lists and bytearrays are mutable
items.body:
This may be a bit of an edge case, but this breaks any python implementation of `dict = loads('cbor map')` since by default Arrays are interpreted as lists.

An actual use case would be storing Markov Chains which are usually represented as a sequence of tokens as the key, with the following likely tokens stored as a list of values.

Here's a failing test case:

```python
@pytest.mark.parametrize('payload, expected', [
    ('A18201026178', {(1, 2): 'x'})
])
def test_map(payload, expected):
    decoded = loads(unhexlify(payload))
    assert decoded == expected
```

A possible solution is to add an argument to any decoder that usually returns a mutable sequence to let it know that it's being called on a map key and to try and return an immutable type instead.

An even more crazy (and related) edge case is an indefinite length byte-stream being used as a map key, like this: `loads(unhexlify('a15f4100ff01'))`

I want to write many objects into one file without use list as proxy since it can be very large amount of data.

How to do it in cbor2 (see cbor works with EOFError pattern)?
It is works in cbor2 looks like bug I get different exception?

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:/Users/Cezary Wagner/PycharmProjects/chess-lichess-eval-parse/sandbox/decode_games/s01_pgn_to_cbor.py", line 42, in <module>
    main()
  File "C:/Users/Cezary Wagner/PycharmProjects/chess-lichess-eval-parse/sandbox/decode_games/s01_pgn_to_cbor.py", line 34, in main

cbor2.decoder.CBORDecodeError: error reading major type at index 10126175: index out of range
```

```
import datetime

import cbor2
from cbor import cbor

from cw_chess.perfect_pgn import PerfectPgnGamesOffsetsParser


def main():
    start_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    with open('../parser_eval/data/out-6976.txt', newline='') as pgn, \
            open('data/games_offsets.cbor', 'wb') as f:
        pgn_games_offset_parser = PerfectPgnGamesOffsetsParser(pgn)

        for game_offset in pgn_games_offset_parser.games_offsets():
            cbor.dump(game_offset, f)
    end_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print(end_time - start_time)

    start_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    with open('data/games_offsets.cbor', 'rb') as f:
        while True:
            try:
                cbor.load(f)
            except EOFError:
                break
    end_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print(end_time - start_time)

    start_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    with open('data/games_offsets.cbor', 'rb') as f:
        while True:
            try:
                cbor2.load(f)
            except EOFError:
                break
    end_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print(end_time - start_time)


if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```

items.title: Truncated byte string inside Tag 24 does not raise exception
items.body:
It's a bit sad but I just reported this issue for the original Python cbor and I find it also applies to cbor2:

If cbor2.loads() encounters a Tag 24 (CBOR-in-CBOR) item whose byte string is accidentally truncated, it does not throw an exception; it simply returns a truncated result. Here's an example. The call 'cbor2.loads(raw2)' should raise an exception, because the Tag 24 length indicates 233 (0xe9) bytes but there are fewer than that. (Carsten Bormann confirms that the Ruby code does raise EOFError in this case.)

Tested on Windows/Python 3.

import cbor2
raw1=bytes.fromhex('')
print(cbor2.loads(raw1))
##outputs: CBORTag(24, b'Y\x00\xe6\x86x&PTR  * Zeroconf._http._tcp.dns-sd.org.\x82x\x18SRV 0 0 80 zeroconf.org.pA 50.197.138.101x\x18TXT "txtvers=1" "path=/"x+PTR  * Multicast DNS._http._tcp.dns-sd.org.\x82x\x1cSRV 0 0 80 multicastdns.org.pA 50.197.138.101x\x18TXT "txtvers=1" "path=/"')
raw2=bytes.fromhex('')
print(cbor2.loads(raw2))
##outputs:  CBORTag(24, b'Y\x00\xe6\x86x&PTR  * Zeroconf._http._tcp.dns-sd.org.\x82x\x18SRV 0 0 80 zeroconf.org.pA 50.197.138.101x\x18TXT "txtvers=1" "path=/"x+PTR  * Multicast DNS._http._tcp.dns-sd.org.\x82x\x1cSRV 0 0 80 multicastdns.org.pA 50.197.138.101x\x18TXT "txtvers=1" ')
print(len(raw1),len(raw2),0xe9)
##outputs:  237, 229, 233

items.title: How to serialize an object with a set as attribute???
items.body:
Hi all,
let's supposed I have the following class:

```
class Point(object):
    def __init__(self, x, y):
        self.x = x
        self.y = y
        self.set = set()
```

I need to serialize and deserialize it. I think the best approach would be to create a new encoder like the following:

```
@shareable_encoder  
    def default_encoder(encoder, value):
       print value
       serialized_state = encoder.encode_to_bytes(value.__dict__)
       encoder.encode(CBORTag(3000, serialized_state))
```

The problem is that a ```set``` object does not have ```__dict__``` how should I approach in this case?

Thanks

items.title: Use OrderedDict to ensure re-encoded CBOR matches original CBOR
items.body:
Currently if you decode a CBOR that contains a map of inner maps and then re-encode the result back to CBOR then the re-encoded CBOR does not match the original CBOR.

This is because Python's dictionary does not preserve the key order. If an OrderedDict is used to represent CBOR maps in Python then this issue can be resolved.

items.title: Error ingesting datetime with fractional seconds
items.body:
When the cbor2.load encounters a text-string-encoded date-time-tagged value which contains fractional seconds, the cbor2 library raises an `cbor2.decoder.CBORDecodeError` exception.

This occurs for string literals, for example '2017-07-22T00:24:07.236Z' and the library also fails loopback reading of library encoded date-times, for example:
`import cbor2
import datetime
import pytz
cbor2.loads(cbor2.dumps(datetime.datetime(2004, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, tzinfo=pytz.utc)))
cbor2.loads(cbor2.dumps(datetime.datetime(2004, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, tzinfo=pytz.utc)))
`
results in exception:
`cbor2.decoder.CBORDecodeError: error decoding value at index 30: microsecond must be in 0..999999`

items.title: Canonical cbor
items.body:
Can this library support canonical encoding

The RFC has some suggestions for canonical encoding, the most important is map ordering. Can this library support the ordering for the maps 

>    o  The keys in every map must be sorted lowest value to highest.
      Sorting is performed on the bytes of the representation of the key
      data items without paying attention to the 3/5 bit splitting for
      major types.  (Note that this rule allows maps that have keys of
      different types, even though that is probably a bad practice that
      could lead to errors in some canonicalization implementations.)
      The sorting rules are:
      *  If two keys have different lengths, the shorter one sorts
         earlier;
      *  If two keys have the same length, the one with the lower value
         in (byte-wise) lexical order sorts earlier.
